title: 115_hr4732
content: The Act is titled the "National Law Enforcement Museum Commemorative Coin Act." The National Law Enforcement Museum Act was passed in 2000 to authorize the construction of the National Law Enforcement Museum in Washington D.C. Construction began in April 2016, and the museum is set to open in September 2018 to honor and commemorate law enforcement officers in the United States. The National Law Enforcement Museum Act was passed in 2000 to honor and commemorate the service and sacrifice of America's law enforcement officers, bridge the past and present of law enforcement, and increase public support for law enforcement safety. SEC. 3. COIN SPECIFICATIONS. The Secretary of the Treasury will mint and issue $5 gold coins, $1 silver coins, and half-dollar clad coins with specific weights, diameters, and gold/silver content. The coins minted under this Act will be legal tender and considered numismatic items. The coins minted under this Act will be legal tender and considered numismatic items. Design of coins. The design of the coins minted under this Act shall symbolize the National Law Enforcement Museum and the service of law enforcement officers in the US. Each coin will include the coin's value, the year "2021", and inscriptions of "Liberty", "In God We Trust", "United States of America", and "E Pluribus Unum". The design will be chosen by the Secretary in consultation with the Commission of Fine Arts and the National Law Enforcement Officers Memorial Fund, Inc. The design of the coins minted under this Act will symbolize the National Law Enforcement Museum and the service of law enforcement officers in the US. The design will be chosen by the Secretary in consultation with the Commission of Fine Arts, the National Law Enforcement Officers Memorial Fund, Inc., and reviewed by the Citizens Coinage Advisory Committee. SEC. 5. ISSUANCE OF COINS. Coins minted under this Act will be issued in uncirculated and proof qualities from a single US Mint facility within a 1-year period starting on January 1, 2021. SEC. 6. SALE OF COINS. The coins will be sold by the Secretary at a price including face value, surcharge, and cost of designing. Bulk sales will be offered at a discount, and prepaid orders will be accepted with a reasonable discount. All sales of coins issued under this Act will include surcharges of $35 per $5 coin, $10 per $1 coin, and $5 per half-dollar coin. Surcharges received will be promptly paid to the National Law Enforcement Officers Memorial Fund for educational programs. The Fund will be audited for the amounts received. No surcharge may be included for the issuance of any coin under this Act. The Secretary of the Treasury may issue guidance to limit the number of commemorative coin programs issued in a calendar year to avoid exceeding the annual issuance limitation.
